#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=Deqin
#Text=Deqin
#Text=( 德钦 ; Déqīn ) is a county in the Hengduanshan Mountains in Yunnan province . 80 % of its 55,000 inhabitants are Tibetan .
#Text=If you can deal with the altitude ( 3,550m ) it makes a great place to hike from , and if you can not then just hanging out in town is also very rewarding .
#Text=A small piece of Tibet , accessible without expensive permits .

#Text=Deqin is in Kham , a former Tibetan province much of which is now administered by Yunnan ; the local dialect is Khampa Tibetan , somewhat different from the central-Tibet dialect of our Tibetan phrasebook but still mostly mutually intelligible .
#Text=The town serves as a base for treks into a number of mountainous areas ; in particular Three Parallel Rivers National Park .
#Text=Understand
#Text=Deqin town is a terrible manifestation of the worst kind of modern Chinese architecture : dirty , white-tiled , and soulless .
#Text=However , if you love hiking Deqin is a superb base .

#Text=If you are not a hiker you might be disappointed , though a short ride out of town does provide a great view of Meilixue Mountain , which could justify the six-hour bus ride from Zhongdian ( Shangrila ) .

#Text=Deqin prefecture is where the big mountains are to be found with impossibly steep valleys , mind-blowing vistas , remote monasteries and class A trekking , for all levels , available all year round .
#Text=In fact the best time to trek is during the winter months as summer is the rainy season .
#Text=March is the worst month as the rains start but it 's still cold enough so it comes down as snow .
#Text=This is the month to get snowed in .
#Text=So , if Deqin is so great , why is it not better known ?
#Text=The main reason for this is that there is not a lot of information available on the area , so the average traveller is left guessing whether it is worth visiting or not .
#Text=The fact that most travellers will have to return the way they came also puts them off visiting ( Deqin is the last town before Tibet proper in Yunnan province ) .
#Text=Here are ten good reasons to visit Deqin :
#Text=1 .
#Text=Mt Kawakarpo & Mt . Miantsomo
#Text=2 .
#Text=Trek up to the Mingyong Glacier
#Text=3 .
#Text=Trekking to Yubeng
#Text=4 .
#Text=Trekking along the Mekong River
#Text=5 .
#Text=Tashi 's Mountain Lodge , Reringkha village ( closed )
#Text=6 .
#Text=To organize a road trip to Lhasa ( the land route to Tibet is closed for foreigners )
#Text=7 .
#Text=The spectacular drive up from Shangri-la
#Text=8 .
#Text=Deqin 's Tibetan Disco ( most are closed )
#Text=9 .
#Text=Sleeping in remote Tibetan villages
#Text=10 .
#Text=Special ginger , lemon tea
#Text=Get in
#Text=There are four buses leaving in the morning from Zhongdian .
#Text=The journey takes about 5 hours and is through spectacular and scary mountain scenery .
#Text=The awful music videos , the freezing cold , windy roads and the chain-smoking fellow-passengers can make the journey a bit unpleasant .
#Text=The town of Benzilan , which lies about midway from Zhongdian is worth stopping off at in its own right , and breaks the journey up nicely .
#Text=The bus drops people throughout the town , ending at the bus station next to a T junction .
#Text=Buses to Zhongdian ( Shangri-la ) depart at 7:30AM , 8:30AM , 9:30AM , 10:20AM and cost ¥ 53 ( June 2011 ) .
#Text=The schedule after 10:20AM is not fixed , but if there are passengers , there might be a bus at noon or a little bit earlier .
#Text=The earlier buses make a lunch stop at a restaurant but be sure to check prices before taking your food ( about ¥ 10 - 15 for a vegetable dish and ¥ 20 for a meat dish ) .
#Text=In June 2012 , the buses between Zhongdian and Deqin took around 8 hours because the road was under major reconstruction .
#Text=Buses to/from Lhasa use the main bus terminal in Deqin .
#Text=There should be no problems buying tickets which are ¥ 500 .
#Text=The ride takes 3-4 days and the bus may or may not stop at hotels during the night .
#Text=There is one military check point where a soldier may come on board , but they seem not to care if there are foreigners on the bus .
#Text=However , the drivers will not let you roam far during restaurant stops in towns .
#Text=This trip is risky if you are not in good health because the bus drives over 5,000m at least three times .
#Text=The land route from Shangri-la to Lhasa is closed for foreigners .
#Text=They will not sell you a ticket even if you have the Tibet travel permit .
#Text=See Yunnan tourist trail for the route from Kunming to Deqin , and Overland to Tibet for land routes to Lhasa .
#Text=Get around
#Text=The town has one through road winding down from the north side .
#Text=See
#Text=Feilai Temple
#Text=( 飞来寺 ; Fēiláisì ) ( 10km away , ¥ 30 by taxi ) .
#Text=Amazing view of Meilixue Mountain worth seeing at sunrise .
#Text=Feilai Temple also has a large number of hostels and hotels .
#Text=Consider staying there instead of Deqin .
#Text=The owner of " Once Upon a Time in FeiLaiSi " speaks English and can give advice on hiking in the area .
#Text=Yubeng
#Text=Village
#Text=( 雨崩村 ; Yǔbēngcūn ) ( 18km away ) .
#Text=Tibetan village not accessible by any vehicles .
#Text=You can ask at your hostel to book a seat for you in one of the minibuses departing every morning from FeiLaiSi to Xidang Hot
#Text=Springs（西当温泉[xīdāngwēnquán]）where the hike starts .
#Text=There are usually 6-7 seats in a bus and an overall price is ¥ 150 ( June 2011 ) .
#Text=Talk to the other people planning to go there so you can share the price .
#Text=There are a decent number of domestic Chinese tourists that make this trek , so finding a lift should n't be difficult .
#Text=It takes 1½ hours to get there and you will be asked to pay ¥ 260 ( May 2014 ) as a scenic area entrance fee .
#Text=Make sure you bring your passport as you have to be registered .
#Text=With a student card you can get a half-price ticket .
#Text=The 9-km ( one way ) hike takes about 6-7 hours in total ( 6.5 km uphill and 2.5 km downhill ) with 1284 meters vertical gain .
#Text=For those who find the hike difficult there is an option of hiring a horse or mule for ¥ 255 to the top or ¥ 305 for the whole way ( May 2014 ) .
#Text=There are 2 tea-houses on the way up where you can buy some water , red bull and simple snacks and a tea-house at the top of Yakou pass .
#Text=The accommodation in Yubeng are basic and costs about ¥ 20 - 30 for a bunk bed ( May 2014 ) .
#Text=Food though is relatively expensive in Yubeng due to the transportation cost andOnce there , Yubeng is one of the most picturesque villages you could hope to see .
#Text=Nestled in an alpine valley , surrounded by snow peaks , multicoloured forests , and waterfalls .
#Text=There are also numerous treks one can make from the village , so plan to spend at least a couple of days there .
#Text=Meilixue Mountain Nature Reserve
#Text=( 梅里雪山景区 ; Méilǐxuěshān Jǐngqū ; also known as Snow Mountain ) ( you can arrange transport to the reserve entrance for around ¥ 50 per person in a shared 4x4 ) .
#Text=Hike to the Taizi Temple and Minyong Glacier .
#Text=Taizi Temple has a guest house but unfortunately most of the rooms are severely damaged by a storm , there is still a few acceptable rooms , available at very low prices ¥ 20 .
#Text=Only recommended if you absolutely have to stay on the mountain , otherwise go back down to Mingyong Town ( July 2009 ) .
#Text=¥ 60 .
